message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug shown to reduce suicide-related mortality is likely to be an antidepressant. Since the patient was stabilized on fluoxetine and denies taking any medications that could poison her brain, it is likely that she was prescribed fluoxetine. A potential adverse outcome of fluoxetine when taken during pregnancy is atrialization of the right ventricle in the fetus. Tardive dyskinesia and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are potential adverse outcomes of antipsychotic medications, not antidepressants. Weight loss is a common side effect of fluoxetine, but it is not a potential adverse outcome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug mentioned as reducing suicide-related mortality is likely lithium, which is known to have adverse effects on the fetus if taken during pregnancy, including cardiac malformations such as atrialization of the right ventricle. Tardive dyskinesia is a potential adverse effect of antipsychotic medications, not fluoxetine. Weight loss is a potential side effect of fluoxetine, but it is unlikely to be considered an adverse outcome in this case. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare but serious skin reaction to certain medications, including some antidepressants, but it is not a known adverse effect of fluoxetine.
